===Etymology 1===
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=irr|さ|k1=しゃ|み|せん|sort=しゃみせん}}
Originally from {{der|ja|ryu|sort=しゃみせん|蛇皮線|tr=jabisen|lit=snakeskin strings}}, so named for the way the [[soundbox]] is traditionally covered in [[snakeskin]]. The traditional ''jabisen'' instrument was imported into the Sakai area of Osaka during the [[永禄|Eiroku]] era (1558-1570), then later modified by [[biwa]] [[luthier]]s to have the square-shaped ''shamisen'' soundbox of today.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref><ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref>

The reading ''jabisen'' shifted over time to ''jamisen'' ({{m|ja|蛇味線}}), replacing the {{m|ja|皮|tr=bi||skin, leather}} character with {{m|ja|味|tr=mi}} for phonetic reasons (i.e. as {{ateji|sort=しゃみせん}}). Then ''jabisen'' changed to ''shamisen'', replacing the {{m|ja|蛇|tr=ja||snake}} character with {{m|ja|三|tr=sha</i>, usually read ''san''||three}} for semantic reasons (i.e. as {{juku|sort=しゃみせん}}). The ''sha'' reading for the {{m|ja|三}} character is irregular.

====Pronunciation====
{{ja-pron|y=i|しゃみせん|acc=0|acc_ref=DJR,SMK5,NHK}}

====Noun====
{{ja-noun|しゃみせん}}

# {{lb|ja|sort=しゃみせん|musical instruments}} a [[shamisen]]: a Japanese [[stringed instrument]] played by [[pluck]]ing, vaguely similar to a [[banjo]]

===Etymology 2===
{{ja-kanjitab|さん|k1=さ|み|せん}}
Sound shift from ''shamisen'' above, possibly influenced by the standard ''san'' reading of the initial {{m|ja|三}} character.

This reading appears to be less common than ''shamisen''.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref><ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref>
